translated: Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 1057
Composed by 500 great arhats and others
Tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully received
Do they obtain the past?
Such chapters and the meaning of the chapters
Having understood, one should extensively distinguish.
Question: Why compose this treatise?
Answer: In order to stop the tenets of others and reveal one's own meaning.
That is to say, some hold the view
That the past and future do not exist, but say that the present is the unconditioned dharma.
In order to refute this view and show that the past and future exist, and the present is not unconditioned, this treatise is composed.
Why is it so?
If there is no past or future,
There should be no sentient beings who accomplish those dharmas,
And also no non-accomplishment, like a second head,
A third hand,
A sixth aggregate,
A thirteenth sense base,
A nineteenth element, and so forth.
There is no accomplishment or non-accomplishment.
However, there are those who attain past and future,
and those who do not attain. Therefore, we know that it truly exists.
Or, there are those who hold the view that
attainment is not a real existent dharma.
Like the proponents of similes who make such arguments.
The various sentient beings are not apart from those dharmas.
It is said that they are attained, but this has no real substance.
It is merely a provisional designation made through observation and discrimination.
Like the combination of five fingers called a fist.
Apart from that, it is not a fist, so it does not truly exist.
In the same way, sentient beings are said to be attained without being apart from those dharmas.
Apart from that, they are not attained, so their substance does not truly exist.
Question: Why do they establish this treatise?
Answer: Because it is based on the sutras.
As the sutras say, there is a wheel-turning king who attains the seven treasures.
If this attainment truly exists,
then he should attain other bodies and things that are not sentient beings.
That is to say, if that wheel-turning king attains the treasure of the wheel and the treasure of the divine pearl, then the Dharma is destroyed.
It is also a dharma that is included in the sentient realm.
They are also dharmas that are not sentient beings.
If one possesses the elephant treasure and the horse treasure, then one's destiny is destroyed.
They are also the human realm and also the animal realm.
If one possesses the female treasure, then one's body is destroyed.
They are also male bodies and also female bodies.
If one possesses the treasure of the chief minister and the treasure of the general, then one's karma is destroyed.
They are also kings and also ministers.
To avoid this fault, possession does not really exist.
In order to stop that view and manifest that the substance of possession really exists, this treatise is composed.
If the substance of possession does not really exist, then it contradicts the sutra's statement.
As it is said, one who is still learning possesses eight factors.
One who has exhausted the contaminants and is an arhat possesses ten factors.
If possession does not really exist,
then when the mind of a noble one with contaminants is manifest,
and when one is without mind, one does not possess the noble path of the three times.
How can one possess eight factors and ten factors?
Because the factors are all uncontaminated dharmas.
If what is accomplished does not really exist,
it would also contradict other sÅ«tras.
As other sÅ«tras say:
This pudgala accomplishes good dharmas and bad dharmas.
If what is accomplished does not really exist,ğŸ”½when he produces good dharmas he should not accomplish bad dharmas.
When producing bad dharmas he should not accomplish good dharmas.
When producing indeterminate dharmas he should not accomplish either.
Moreover, if what is accomplished does not really exist,
it would also contradict other sÅ«tras.
As it is said, If a bhiká¹£u accomplishes the seven wonderful dharmas,
he will dwell in joy and happiness in this very life.
He should accomplish one wonderful dharma or not accomplish it.
That is, when one of the seven wonderful dharmas is present,
at that time that bhiká¹£u only accomplishes one.
Because the seven wonderful dharmas are all by nature wisdom.
There is still no arising of two wisdoms, let alone seven.
If other dharmas are present, then the seven wonderful dharmas are all not accomplished.
If it is established that it does not really exist,
it also contradicts other sÅ«tras.
As it is said, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, accomplishes the ten powers.
They should only say that he accomplishes one power.
Or he does not accomplish it.
If one power is present,
the other nine are separated from the body and he does not accomplish them.
Because the ten powers all have wisdom as their essence.
Because two wisdoms do not arise together.
If other dharmas are present,
then the ten powers are all not accomplished.
If it is established that it does not really exist,
there is another error. Ordinary beings should be called separated from the defilements of the three realms.
Arhats should be called ordinary beings.
Because ordinary beings
give rise to wholesome and unobscured indeterminate minds.
And when there is no mind, there are no afflictions present in the body.
And they do not accomplish past and future.
Aren't they called separated from the defilements of the three realms?
When arhats give rise to defiled minds and when there is no mind,
At present, there is no noble path.
Moreover, one does not possess past and future [noble paths].
How can it not be that ordinary beings are without noble dharmas? If so, there would be a great error.
Therefore, possession definitely truly exists.
Question: If possession truly exists,
how can one reconcile this with the sutra cited by the VaibhÄá¹£ikas?
Answer: They say that mastery is called possession.
That is to say, a wheel-turning king has mastery over his own seven treasures.
It is provisionally said that he possesses [the treasures], but not like one who possesses the eight branches of the path of the learner, etc.
Or, there are some who maintain:
Although possession has a real substance,
one who does not possess [the noble dharmas]
does not have a real substance.
In order to refute this view and show that non-possession also has a real substance, this treatise is composed.
If non-possession does not have a real substance,
possession also would not have a real substance.
Because possession is spoken of in view of non-possession.
It is like establishing day in view of night,
and establishing light in view of darkness.
They all have a real substance.ğŸ”½This...
This.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
It is also like this.
Moreover, non-accomplishment is the proximate antidote to accomplishment.
They mutually contradict each other.
Such as non-greed to greed, non-hatred to hatred, non-delusion to delusion, concentration to distraction, etc.
If there is no real substance, what is contradicted to become the proximate antidote?
Moreover, if non-accomplishment has no substance,
one should not establish the cutting off of all afflictions.
That is to say, when the noble path arises, it cuts off all afflictions.

It is not like cutting objects with a knife or grinding objects with a stone. It only severs the attainment of bondage and realizes the attainment of liberation, causing the afflictions to not arise due to non-accomplishment, which is called cutting off.
Therefore, one should know that there is indeed the nature of non-accomplishment.
Or, in order to cut off doubts and nets, this treatise is composed.
The Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama says that past dharmas have arising, aging, abiding, and impermanence, which should be said to be past.
And so on, in detail.
One should not have doubts.
Just as the characteristics are not different from the dharmas,
they are not different from the moments.
Attainment is also like this with regard to the dharmas.
It is like the obtained and the dharma having differences in world and differences in moment.
The characteristics and the dharma are also like this.
In order to make this doubt become certain,
it clarifies that the characteristics and the dharma are definitely not different in world,
and are not different in moment.
But the obtained and the dharma can be the same or different.
This means that dharmas of the three times each have the obtained of the three times.
Question: Why is it that the characteristics and the characterized are definitely without difference in world and moment,
while the obtained and the obtainable are either the same or different?
Answer: The characteristics and the characterized,
necessarily have the same effect.
The characteristics follow along and are inseparable.
There is no before or after.
They cannot abandon the dharmas of the same aggregate.
The obtained and the obtainable do not have the same effect.
They are not necessarily following along, nor are they separable.
Sometimes there is a before or after.
They may or may not abandon the dharmas of the same aggregate.
Like the nature of tree bark is separate from the tree.ğŸ”½Therefore, in order to stop the tenets of others, to reveal one's own meaning, and to make the doubtful become certain,
Therefore, in order to refute the doctrines of others, to manifest one's own meaning, and to enable the doubtful to attain certainty,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
If one does not stop others and reveals oneself, causing doubt to become certain.
But in the meaning of the correspondence of the characteristics of dharmas,
One should reveal what is illuminated, therefore this treatise is composed.
Do those who obtain past dharmas obtain the past?
What is the meaning of the word obtain here?
It means to attain and accomplish.
How do we know this?
As the Abhidharma states:ğŸ”½What is meant by obtain? It means to attain and accomplish.
What is meant by attain?
It means to obtain and accomplish.
What is meant by accomplish?
It means to acquire.
Although the sounds obtain, attain, and accomplish are different, their meanings are not different.
The dharmas that are obtained are of eleven kinds.
The desire realm has four:ğŸ”½Good, bad,
obscured neutral,
and unobscured neutral.
The form realm has three:
Excluding the bad.
The formless realm is also like this.
And the pure dharmas.
The good, bad, and unobscured neutral dharmas of the desire realm each possess the five aggregates.

The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.

The four formless meditative attainments are the objects of the four formless meditative attainments.ğŸ”½The four formless meditative attainments
For the most part, the four aggregates obtained by them are not mixed in terms of time and not mixed in terms of moment.
If they are in the past, the obtainment is also past.
If they are in the future, the obtainment is also future.
If they are in the present, the obtainment is also present.
In the four aggregates of the path of deportment,
those who are well-trained, like the Buddha and AÅ›vajit,
and other sentient beings who are well-trained,
and in the four aggregates of the skillful crafts, those who are well-trained,
like the Buddha's son ViÅ›vakarman,
and other sentient beings who are well-trained,
their obtainment is also mixed in terms of time and mixed in terms of moment.
That is to say, in the three times, there are obtainments of the three times.
Therefore, the five aggregates of wholesome and obscured-neutral dharmas in the form realm,
and among the unobscured-neutral dharmas,
the four aggregates that arise together with the mind of the supernormal powers,
their obtainment is mixed in terms of time and mixed in terms of moment.
That is to say, in the three times, there are obtainments of the three times, therefore it is indeterminate.
The wholesome aggregate of form is like the wholesome and unwholesome aggregate of form in the desire realm.
It refers to the form aggregate that is all-encompassing, obscured-neutral, and unobscured-neutral,
as well as the four aggregates that are posturing, karmic ripening, and born of maturation.
Those obtainments are mixed in terms of world but not mixed in terms of moment.
Following which world they are in,
there are only those of that world's obtainment.
Therefore, the four aggregates that are wholesome and obscured-neutral in the formless realm have obtainment that is mixed in terms of world and mixed in terms of moment.
This is because they are in the three time periods and each has obtainment in the three time periods.
The four aggregates that are born of maturation have obtainment that is not mixed in terms of world but not mixed in terms of moment.
Following which world they are in,
there are only those of that world's obtainment.
The obtainment of the five uncontaminated aggregates
is also mixed in terms of world and mixed in terms of moment.
This is because they are in the three time periods and each has obtainment in the three time periods.
This is the general explanation.
If explained separately,
the five uncontaminated aggregates that have never been obtained,ğŸ”½as well as the contaminated cultivated aggregates that have never been obtained,
and the aggregates born of hearing and contemplation that have never been obtained,
are initially obtained.
If it is in the future, that dharma only has future attainment.
If it is in the present, that dharma has future and present attainment.
If it is in the past, that dharma has attainment of the three time periods.
Although the dharmas of cessation through discrimination and cessation not through discrimination are not categorized as the three time periods, they have attainment of the three time periods.
However, the attainment of cessation through discrimination is of two kinds.
Namely, contaminated and uncontaminated.ğŸ”½The attainment of contaminated cessation through discrimination
arises due to being free from the contamination of the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness.
This is the class of worldly paths.
If one has not yet been free from contamination, that cessation only has past and future attainment.
If one has already been free from contamination, that cessation
then has attainment of the three time periods.
The attainment of uncontaminated cessation through discrimination
arises due to being free from the contamination of the three realms that is eliminated by insight and cultivation.
The cessation through discrimination of dharmas eliminated by insight into suffering in the desire realm
if the cognition of the dharma of suffering is not presently manifest, that cessation only has future attainment.
If it is present, then the acquisition of that which has ceased is future and present.
If it has already ceased,
then the acquisition of that which has ceased has the three times.
In this way, up to the ninth category of dharmas of the peak of existence and cessation through discernment,
if the knowledge of elimination has not yet appeared, etc., it should be understood according to reason.
The acquisition of cessation not resulting from consideration is only contaminated.
Their initial acquisition,
if in the future, then the acquisition of that which has ceased exists only in the future.
If in the present, then the acquisition of that which has ceased is future and present. If in the past, then the acquisition of that which has ceased has the three times.
Here, the first question and answer shows that each category of dharmas of the three times has the acquisition of the three times.
The second question and answer shows that each acquisition of the three times has the acquisition of the three times and the dharmas apart from the three times.
This is called the brief discussion here.
If one acquires past dharmas, does one acquire them in the past?
The answer is: One acquires them in the past,
or in the future,
or in the present.
Acquiring past dharmas, past acquisition,
Namely, the past aggregates of all three realms,
and the past attainments of the pure aggregates.
Obtaining past dharmas.
As for future attainments,
it refers to the wholesome and unwholesome five aggregates of the desire realm in the past,
the four aggregates with hindrances and without hindrances,
and the category of dharmas arising together with the resultant mind without hindrances in the indeterminate [category].
And the four aggregates of the one part of deportment and craftsmanship.
The wholesome five aggregates of the form realm,
and the four aggregates with hindrances and without hindrances in the indeterminate [category],
and the category of dharmas arising together with the resultant mind without hindrances.
The wholesome four aggregates and the four aggregates with hindrances in the formless realm,
and the future attainments of the pure five aggregates.
Obtaining past dharmas.
As for present attainments,
it refers to the wholesome and unwholesome five aggregates of the desire realm in the past,
and so on in detail.

The answer is: Those dharmas may be past,

Are those attainments future?
Answer: Those attainments may be future,
past,
or present.
Attaining future dharmas.
Future attainments.
It refers to all the aggregates of the three realms in the future,
and the uncontaminated aggregates.
The future attainments of those.
Attaining future dharmas.
Past attainments.
It refers to the four aggregates of wholesome, unwholesome, and obscured-neutral dharmas in the desire realm in the future,
and among the unobscured-neutral [dharmas],
the category arising together with the mind of the special attainment,

The five aggregates of wholesome dharmas in the form realm,

The four aggregates of wholesome and obscured-neutral dharmas in the formless realm.

Attaining future dharmas.

it refers to the future wholesome [dharmas] of the desire realm,
and so on, as extensively explained like the past.
As for the present obtainment that it possesses,
if one obtains the future, does one obtain future dharmas?
The answer is: those dharmas may be future,ğŸ”½may be past,

may be unconditioned.
Future obtainment.
As for obtaining future dharmas,
it refers to future obtainment.
Future obtainment obtains all the aggregates of the three realms and the undefiled aggregates in the future.
Future obtainment.
As for obtaining past dharmas,
it refers to future obtainment.
Future obtainment obtains the wholesome and unwholesome five aggregates of the desire realm in the past, and the four aggregates that are obscured and neutral.
Among the unobscured and neutral [dharmas],

The wholesome five aggregates of the form realm,

Do all attainments of present dharmas attain the present?
The answer is: They may attain the present,
Or the past,
Or the future.
Attaining present dharmas,
Present attainment.
It refers to the present aggregates of the three realms and the uncontaminated aggregates, and their present attainments.
Attaining present dharmas,
Past attainment.

Among the unobscured neutral,ğŸ”½The class of dharmas arising together with the supernormal powers,
And a part of the four aggregates of deportment and craftsmanship.

Among the obscured indeterminate and unobscured indeterminate [dharmas],

The five uncontaminated aggregates.
The acquisition of those [dharmas] that exist in the past,
acquires present dharmas.
The acquisition of those [dharmas] that exist in the future,
refers to the wholesome and unwholesome five aggregates of the desire realm in the present,
the four aggregates that are obscured indeterminate,
and the rest are explained as the acquisition of those in the past.
The acquisition of those [dharmas] that exist in the future,
even if acquired in the present,
does that acquisition acquire present dharmas?
Answer: Those dharmas may be present,
or past, or future,
or unconditioned. The present acquisition
acquires present dharmas.
That is to say, the present acquisition

it refers to the present obtainment of obtaining cessation through deliberation and cessation not through deliberation.
If one obtains wholesome dharmas, does one obtain wholesome attainment?
The answer is: It is so. Because obtaining wholesome dharmas is necessarily wholesome.
If one obtains wholesome attainment, does one obtain wholesome dharmas?
The answer is: It is so.
Because the acquisition of wholesome dharmas is only the acquisition of wholesome dharmas.
The answers for unwholesome and indeterminate dharmas are also the same.
Because the nature of what is acquired and the acquisition must be the same.
Obtaining dharmas of the desire realm,
is that acquisition of the desire realm?
The answer is: It is so.
Because the acquisition of dharmas of the desire realm is necessarily of the desire realm.
If there is acquisition of the desire realm, is that acquisition of dharmas of the desire realm?
The answer is: Those dharmas may be of the desire realm,
or unconditioned.ğŸ”½Those of the desire realm
refer to the five aggregates of the desire realm.
The unconditioned refers to the cessation not due to deliberation.
Because a person born in the desire realm
obtains the cessation not due to deliberation of dharmas bound to the three realms and unconditioned.
Because that acquisition is all bound to the desire realm.
Obtaining dharmas of the form realm,
is that acquisition of the form realm?
The answer is: It is so.
Because the acquisition of dharmas of the form realm is necessarily of the form realm.
If there is acquisition of the form realm,
is that acquisition of dharmas of the form realm?
The answer is: Those dharmas may be of the form realm or unconditioned.
The form realm means:
The five aggregates of the form realm.
The unconditioned means:
The cessation through deliberation and the cessation not through deliberation.
The cessation through deliberation means:
The cessation through deliberation of the five aggregates of the lower three meditations of the desire realm.
The class of the conventional path
All belong to the form realm.
Because the contaminated attainment of the cessation through deliberation of the lower stages is included in the proximity stage of the higher stages. The cessation not through deliberation means:
The person born in the form realm
Attains the cessation not through deliberation of the dharmas bound to the three realms and the unconditioned.
Because that attainment all belongs to the form realm.
All attainments of the formless realm dharmas
Do those attainments belong to the formless realm?
Answer: It is so.
Because the attainments of the formless realm dharmas all belong to the formless realm.
If one attains the formless realm, do those attainments belong to the formless realm dharmas?
Answer: Those dharmas may be of the formless realm or unconditioned.
The formless realm means:
The four aggregates of the formless realm.
The unconditioned means:
Namely, the cessation through discrimination and the cessation not through discrimination.
Namely, the cessation through discrimination and the cessation not through discrimination.ğŸ”½As for the cessation through discrimination,
it refers to the five aggregates bound to the fourth meditative absorption stage,
and the cessation through discrimination of the four aggregates bound to the three lower formless stages.
The acquisition of the subsequent mundane path is all bound to the formless realm.
The reason is as explained above.
As for the cessation not through discrimination,
it refers to the person born in the formless realm.
The acquisition of the cessation not through discrimination of the dharmas bound to the three realms and the unbound [dharmas]
is all bound to the formless realm.
Do all acquisitions of learner dharmas belong to learners?
The answer is: Yes.
Because the acquisition of learner dharmas must be that of a learner.
If one acquires the dharmas of a learner, do they belong to a learner?
The answer is: Those dharmas may be of a learner,
or neither a learner nor post-learner. The learner refers to the five aggregates of a learner.
The neither learner nor post-learner
refers to the acquisition of a learner.
The cessation acquired
Do all acquisitions of post-learner dharmas belong to post-learners?
The answer is: Yes.
Because the attainment of the dharmas of no-more-learning is necessarily that of no-more-learning.
If one attains the dharmas of no-more-learning, does one attain the dharmas of no-more-learning?
Answer: Those dharmas may be of no-more-learning.
Or they may be neither of learning nor of no-more-learning.
Those of no-more-learning are:
The five aggregates of no-more-learning.
Those neither of learning nor of no-more-learning are:
The cessation obtained by the attainment of no-more-learning.
The attainments of the dharmas neither of learning nor of no-more-learning.
Do they attain the dharmas neither of learning nor of no-more-learning?
Answer: They attain those dharmas either neither of learning nor of no-more-learning,
Or of learning or of no-more-learning.
Those neither of learning nor of no-more-learning are:
The five contaminated aggregates and the four aggregates.
The attainment of all non-discriminative cessations.
The attainment of the cessation obtained through the worldly path and the class of the path.
The attainment of those of learning is:
The cessation obtained through the path of learning.
The attainment of those of no-more-learning is:

The answer is: Those dharmas may be learners,
